content.title: Transparency, Public Confidence and Trust in Institutions

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

Open and transparent institutions are essential for a successful energy governance, ensuring trust, accountability, and effective policymaking. Corruption risks—such as state capture, bribery, and embezzlement—can undermine progress, making strong governance and data-driven transparency critical. This lesson explores how transparency enhances public confidence, facilitates investment, and promotes efficient resource allocation in the energy sector.

Transparency in energy governance involves the open disclosure of information related to policy decisions, financial flows, and project implementations. Such openness allows stakeholders—including governments, businesses, civil society, and the general public—to access pertinent information, thereby facilitating informed decision-making and fostering accountability.

In the context of the energy transition, transparency serves multiple critical functions: Enhancing Public Trust When institutions operate transparently, they build credibility and trust among citizens. This trust is vital for public acceptance of energy policies, especially when such policies require significant behavioral or economic adjustments from the populace. Facilitating Investment Transparent markets attract investors by reducing informational asymmetries and perceived risks. Investors are more likely to fund renewable energy projects when they have clear insights into regulatory frameworks, financial incentives, and market operations. Promoting Efficient Resource Allocation Transparency ensures that resources allocated for the energy transition are used effectively. It allows for the monitoring of fund disbursement and project execution, thereby minimizing waste and mismanagement.

The Green Bond Transparency Platform, Inter-American Development Bank[ The Green Bond Transparency Platform (GBTP), launched in April 2021 by the Inter-American Development Bank and IDB Invest, exemplifies how transparency can drive sustainable energy investments. This platform aims to increase transparency in the green bond market, facilitating reporting and verification of green investments.

Within a year of its launch, the GBTP became the primary reporting tool for 73% of the green bond market in Latin America and the Caribbean, representing $26.8 billion in investments. The GBTP enhances transparency by enabling issuers and external reviewers to report directly on the use of green bond proceeds and their development impacts in a secure, blockchain-enabled environment. This ensures the integrity and reliability of data, which builds investor confidence and facilitates greater participation in the green bond market. By providing verifiable insights into the performance of sustainable energy investments, the platform shows the importance of transparency in scaling sustainable energy initiatives and demonstrates how robust governance can accelerate the transition to renewable energy.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Corruption Risks in the Energy Transition

content.text: Despite the noble objectives of the energy transition, it is susceptible to various forms of corruption that can undermine its effectiveness and fairness: State Capture This occurs when powerful individuals, groups, or corporations manipulate policy formation and regulatory environments to serve their interests at the expense of the public good. In the energy sector, this could manifest as the prioritization of projects that benefit a select few rather than addressing broader societal needs. Bribery and Cronyism Corruption can infiltrate the procurement processes of energy projects, leading to the selection of contractors based on favoritism rather than merit. Such practices can result in substandard work, inflated costs, and projects that do not meet the intended environmental or social objectives. Embezzlement and Fraud The substantial funds allocated for energy projects can be misappropriated by corrupt officials or business entities, leading to project delays, failures, or the complete derailment of energy transition efforts.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Mitigating Corruption Risks and Enhancing Transparency In the Energy Transition

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. Build Strong Foundations for Clean Governance

content.text: These are enabling actions that establish the baseline capacities and frameworks necessary for transparent, accountable energy transition governance. Strengthen Enforcement of Anti-Corruption Laws Even where anti-corruption laws exist, enforcement is often weak. National governments must increase the capacity and independence of anti-corruption bodies—through staffing, training, legal autonomy, and budget protections—to enable effective investigation and prosecution. Promote Adoption and Implementation of Anti-Corruption Instruments Countries should ratify and align national policies with global and regional frameworks such as the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC). Development partners can support legal harmonization and institutional strengthening to uphold these commitments. Provide Capacity-Building for Fund Administration Invest in the capacity of ministries, national funds, and procurement bodies to manage climate and energy finance transparently. This includes adopting digital public financial management systems, modern procurement platforms, and training programs. Consolidate and Streamline Funding Channels Reduce fragmentation in funding structures by establishing unified financing platforms, integrating reporting systems, and ensuring centralized oversight. This limits leakages and increases efficiency in tracking climate-related expenditures.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B. Institutionalize Oversight and Risk Management

content.text: These actions support the creation of structured mechanisms to identify risks and enable real-time accountability. Conduct Corruption Risk Assessments Regulators and ministries should conduct regular, sector-specific corruption risk assessments (CRAs) to identify vulnerabilities, especially in procurement, licensing, and subsidy disbursement. These assessments should guide the design of targeted safeguards. Support and Strengthen Independent Anti-Corruption Bodies Beyond enforcement, anti-corruption commissions should be empowered to conduct system audits, advise on integrity in public-private partnerships, and provide early warning indicators to avoid reputational or financial risks. Implement Multi-Stakeholder Accountability Mechanisms Introduce governance structures where civil society, the private sector, and affected communities participate in project design, budget allocation, and monitoring. Independent oversight boards or social audit mechanisms can add layers of scrutiny and legitimacy.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | C
content.title: C. Enable Inclusive and Localized Accountability

content.text: To build public trust and reach underserved populations, accountability must be community-driven and locally grounded. Enhance Local Governance Transparency and Accountability Local authorities should adopt participatory planning, transparent procurement, and accessible grievance redress mechanisms. Projects should include budget disclosures at the municipal level and community monitoring systems. Empower Civil Society as Independent Watchdogs Civil society organizations must be resourced and protected to monitor energy transition projects. Legal protections for whistleblowers, access to public data, and avenues for lodging complaints can enable them to expose misuse and demand reform.

content.intro: M5: Energy Governance for a Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: The Role of Data in enhancing transparency In Energy Governance

content.text: Data governance plays a crucial role in improving transparency in the energy sector by ensuring the accuracy, integrity, and accessibility of energy-related data. This enhanced transparency contributes to better decision-making, increased public trust, and more effective energy policies. For example, IRENA identifies opacity and fragmentation of existing data as key transparency challenges for the energy transition, potentially leading to poor investment decisions and supply chain disruptions. Energy policy modeling and planning should be informed by data and analytics covering key governance factors such as institutional effectiveness, the rule of law, transparency, political economy, and civic engagement.

Access to reliable information and quality data, both internally and externally, are critical when developing an effective energy transition. First steps to strengthening sustainable energy data systems include: · Advocate for data transparency by pushing for centralized repositories of energy data and encouraging governments to make data available for public download, enabling independent analyses. · Create formal protocols for data sharing with clear access guidelines, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data for monitoring emissions, energy efficiency, and renewable energy progress. · Promote capacity building through institutional training on energy reporting guidelines, encourage collaboration with international partners to share knowledge, and leverage resources.
IEA’s Designing an energy statistics roadmap Assessment tool

The IEA guidebook provides a comprehensive framework for strengthening national energy information systems, crucial for tracking progress in clean energy transitions. It addresses the need for robust, accurate, and accessible energy data to inform policy decisions, monitor efficiency, and assess emissions and renewable energy goals. Developed through consultations with countries and experts, the guidebook outlines a three-dimensional strategy for improving data collection: planning, setting up infrastructure, and tracking data quality and accessibility.

It offers practical steps and best practices, emphasizing the importance of governance, resource allocation, and innovation, such as digitization. Targeted especially at developing countries, the guidebook helps assess energy data systems, identify gaps, and create tailored action plans. By aligning with international standards, it supports transparency, governance effectiveness, and data-driven policymaking for sustainable energy transitions.

UNDP has worked with 126 developing countries to improve their transparency in line with the Modalities, Procedures and Guidelines (MPGs). This support originated from numerous global programmes and bilateral donor-supported projects, such as the Low Emission Capacity Development Programme (2011-2018), the NDC Support Programme (2017-2023), the Climate Compromise (2019-) and several Global Environment Facility projects.
MRV tracking visualization platform in Uruguay

During the development of its Third Biennial Update Report, Uruguay implemented a domestic Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system in the form of a database of policies and measures, relevant emissions reductions or avoided emissions, and information on adaptation, technology transfer, financing, capacity-building, and mitigation (UNDP, 2022). Also included in the system are technical sheets and methodologies that define indicators towards the implementation of different measures.

In June 2019, a visualization platform was created and made publicly available on the Ministry of Environment website to inform Uruguayan citizens of the progress made towards the goal for each measure, its contribution to the National Climate Change Policy, and the SDGs, as well as a classification on each measure’s gender sensitivity. (UNDP, 2022d)

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

cards.title: Transparency is the cornerstone of energy governance, ensuring public trust, efficient resource allocation, and investment confidence in the energy transition.

Corruption risks, including state capture, bribery, and embezzlement, threaten the effectiveness of the energy transition, making strong governance, accountability, and data-driven decision-making essential.

Innovative tools like the Green Bond Transparency Platform and MRV systems showcase how digital transparency solutions can strengthen oversight, accelerate sustainable energy investments, and enhance public confidence.
